saying "they should be lucky to even have a job!!1!1!1!!!!1!" is like saying you're lucky to be alive. the fact is undeniable - you are indeed *lucky*, but lucky =/= humane. ignoring circumstances and environment is borderline delusional........you're lucky to be alive even though you're thousands of dollars in debt and you have to feel like a parasite wherever you go? content and bad situations are not mutually exclusive. why can't you be "happy" with something and acknowledge it's shitty at the same time? not saying you're wrong in saying "omg they lucky enough bro" (just incredulity if anything) but there are 2 sides of the coin. sure, they feel fortunate enough to have a job that pays wages above the ones in their home country, but it is also a fact that MW *have* voiced out terrible living conditions. must one live in fear? not being able to voice out their personal concerns with the threat of being fired. by that logic, you might as well tell MOM to eradicate TAFEP. why bother complaining about your shitty employer when you're lucky he gave you a job? plssssss. do better. be better.

So you see the issue is not so much a lack of resources but myths that have been propagated and mindless questions like "are you going to raid our reserves" or "are you going to pay for it" which creates red herrings and false dischotomies. Everything I have said here is well documented in academic papers online. Also it is not my job to come educate you but I do suggest that you consider thinking out of the worldview that we have all been fed since a young age.

answers.text: @shaynephua also @wakeupsingapore doesn't need to reply because the account has many blind followers that will answer the question. It's so obvious that the many followers have 0 idea what's happening because whatever this account post is just to make fun of the govt. Since you said you dont want to waste your time, dont answer I dont expect one.
@gav_nggg you should also check out @sg_activist second latest post (yellow) there’s definitely other examples out there. Just giving you what I can think of. Hope it helps. Thanks.

@shaynephua okay in my view I see that they have sufficient needs and they are fine with it. From all the interviews done with MW they are satisfied, so why should we change anything if they didnt ask for any change? It's like you give sth for free but the person didnt even ask for it. We are in no position to ask for them because we are not them, so stop actually flaming the govt for a sth that isnt even count as an issue.

@bloodycrocodile cool, but check out @sg_activist Instagram page and the second latest post (yellow). And again, we’re not looking at an extremely comfortable place for them right now. We’re not looking into that even. Far from that. I hope you’ll check out that page!😉

@gav_nggg I don’t think @wakeupsingapore has time to bother about your comment. But in anyway, I’m just going to do this for the last time, because I don’t have much time just for this either. There are more poor folks with slave mentality like you out there, than to focus on one. 
So I have to assume that you didn’t read and digest whatever that’s written, judging from your reply. 
1) Nobody is focusing on drawing a comparison on Singaporeans and MWs. 2) And where they come from shouldn’t justify the way we treat them. There’s no need to compare at all. A lot of Singaporeans, unlike you, can judge that their living conditions NEED to be improved. 
3) And nobody is saying we are giving them the needs like an average Singaporean. Their condition is far away from that to take that as a comparison. Again here. You don’t have to make unnecessary comparison. 
4) The government did not do its job to do proper auditing. They did not regulate the living conditions of the migrant workers. They did not make sure proper cleaning services are needed to keep a healthy environment for the workers. Just because companies are “privatised”, it doesn’t mean the government can’t hold accountable. It is their job. And no, they did not enforce basic needs properly! Ask why they can’t instead of  simply claiming they can’t. Ask yourself, and look for the answers. 
5) And no, we’re not a democratic society. We have a very SERIOUS issue on freedom of speech, not only that, the mainstream media is HEAVILY censored. That is exactly why Singaporeans can’t think critically. Your world-view is indeed, very small. And I urge you to read more, learn more, DIGEST and stop fixating on how things is running as the only way. 6) And again, nobody is changing the social economic status. Nobody is talking about that! Do read and digest this entire comments section properly. I hope you learn a thing or two and that you’ll read more in the future.

@wakeupsingapore there is a need to draw a comparison between Singaporeans and MW because let's face it they come from far lower backgrounds than the lowest 10% of our society. Singapore has a shortage of labourers as a result of the majority of our society having proper education. So to mitigate the problem they need to outsource the labour jobs overseas, but the govt cant do that. Only contractors are able to do that which privatises overseas labourers. And private companies are always looking at profits so they do the bare minimum for such workers. This causes the govt to enforce basic needs for the workers. If the govt were to enforce the needs like average singaporeans it would cause the whole socioeconomic ladder in singapore to change. With the socioeconomic ladder changing it can lead to more unnecessary money being spent instead of spending on more essential actions. Being a democratic country, many singaporeans see having a good socioeconomic status is vital so the character of our society cannot change.
@potongpasirarea trickle down economics is a myth.

@wakeupsingapore lastly, and I know of no subtle way to put this, but trickle down economics is complete bullshit. It has been throughly rebutted. If trickle down actually worked inequality would have decreased over the years. Wealth doesn't trickle down from the 1%, it only accumulates.

@wakeupsingapore and dont advance false dichotomies which have been repeatedly debunked by brains way more brilliant than me. You see the issue is that we need to grow out of this mindset that has been inculcated in us

@gav_nggg so you see the issue here is that we have been resorting to the old bogeyman of "welfare bad" or "raiding the reserves" when the fact is that 1) not true and 2) our system requires a fundamental rethink. Especially with such constant and widespread disruption. One example, Govt has always talked bad about handouts and unemployment insurance but when shit hits the fan everyone becomes a little socialist

@gav_nggg a few points. 1. Dont draw a false dichotomy between better wages or living conditions for MWs and ordinary people footing the bill for the same. This is simply not the case for a few reasons. Firstly, the Govt collects billions of dollars (all documented)in FW levy which can easily be used to improve their living conditions. Secondly, many employers have insane profits and so does construction projects like HDB etc. Why not cut their pie of the profits. Thirdly, you and I dont know the size of the reserves. But there are people who have, like Dr Yeoh Lam Keong (go check him out) who has said that we dont even need to raid our reserves, but a fraction of the return on investment of our reserves is more than enough to fund universal healthcare in Singapore.
@shaynephua imagine you living in a place without proper water supplies proper shelter  and proper sanitation. And you have the chance to move into a place like these dormitories.

@shaynephua in our eyes it looks bad but we cannot make decisions for them based on what we think is best for them. They need to make their decisions for themselves  by comparing how they lived throughout their lives. We cannot make the decisions for them because we live very differently from them. This is why you dont see FW coming out and saying their living conditions are bad, the only people saying that their living conditions are bad are singaporeans who live differently. So as a summary we as singaporeans cannot comment on what they need as we do not know what is it like to be in their shoes.

@gav_nggg for your case, what you raise, I think it’s a little ignorant. Can you not see how the condition is like? Have you not been following up on all the issues? You don’t know there’s such thing as not knowing their own rights? So I can pretty much assume you think it’s totally fine for them staying in such environment? And for the “there’s no indication” there’s plenty lots. It’s because you choose not to look at it, or maybe, you’re not exposed to it.
@shaynephua both theys
@shaynephua my they is referring to those at the top, not the government.

@shaynephua it's good to voice out for the foreign workers but right now foreign workers are satisfied with their living conditions and pay so why do singaporeans still voice out to ensure these FW get a better living condition and pay? There is no indication that these workers are unhappy with their current state and here we have singaporeans that have never felt what these workers have gone through before advocating for sth that the FW dont even need!
@shaynephua trickle down economics also has a key factor into play in Singapore in regards to why we don't have to pay high taxes.

@shaynephua their pay isn't necessarily reasonable but it's definitely why they like Singapore so much, because our taxes aren't anywhere near the top few in the world, alongside our booming export based market.

@shaynephua You can check the IRAS website and a quick search about our corporate tax rates will allow you to see that we have a pretty low tax rate of 17% as well as a fair amount of tax exemption for starting companies. We are also ranked one of the most open economies and pro business regime. We also make most of our money from exports and our cargo seaport.

@potongpasirarea you must be well read regarding that, I’m really not, I must admit.. Could you recommend me readings regarding how their high pay salary is reasonable and why it’s supporting our economics and how their high salary equate to us paying lesser tax?  If possible. Thanks!

@potongpasirarea At least it can make a little difference in the living condition... At least a well regulated clean environment? Which requires hiring of more workers for this task? And better auditing from the government side? Proper on-time payment? Allow NGOs to work closely with governments and employers.(give them a better platform to do so & acknowledge them) And make sure it is that way in the long run. As opposed to an immediate revolutionary raise in pay and large sleeping area. Do we really need that huge amount of money that will affect our lives badly? I’m really not sure... But I want to choose to believe we can improve on a lot of things. And we have to start small first. Before considering if it’s impossible.

@bloodycrocodile Communism was needed, or rather became a “success” exactly because the gap between the rich and the poor is unreasonably wide. However, none of the communist state has achieved communism. 
But no, we’re not asking for an equal distribution of wealth right now, we’re not going into communism, we don’t even have to. We need to fight for a narrower gap in between. Let’s support the advocates, activist. Let’s raise more awareness, so that things that should be changed will have changes made. Let’s not give up when there’s advocates and activist out there who’s fighting for different social causes. They’re there because it’s needed, not because they’re asking for a perfect society where everybody is equal. Basic human rights.. that’s what they’re fighting for.

@shaynephua and I hope you know the people at the TOP of this pyramid is really the main thing supporting our economics. They stay because our tax rates are MUCH MUCH lower than other countries. Getting the top to fork out more is going to be harder than you think if you want them to stay at the same time
@shaynephua do you think a reduction of salary of a few ministers can support THOUSANDS and THOUSANDS of foreign workers?

@shaynephua yes!!! I’d agree but the hard part is getting the people at the top of the pyramid to give! honestly there are so many people in singapore struggling to get by 
it’s kind of like how the idea of communism would be good but isn’t practical. but yeah if everyone who can afford it could give a certain amount to the ones who are struggling that would be ideal
@bloodycrocodile and now what we’re lacking is exactly people who believes it is possible. To believe that we have voice, and we can voice out.

@bloodycrocodile If need be, yes. And yes there are so many of them, but I truly believe what a lot of people fighting for their rights are still at the level of fighting for basic rights- at least a decent living condition. And honestly, just a really tiny part of the salary from those at the top of the ‘pyramid’ can do that easily. Before we look at the impossibility, let’s look at the possibility.
@shaynephua but there are so many of them! would you be willing to give a fraction of your salary to them?
@afirdausbak_ but unfortunately that’s not how the whole of Singapore feels wait would you like to donate to an organisation my friend is part of? Its to help the migrant workers!
@bloodycrocodile yes we're willing to pay more.
@thisisalton from the reduction of their salary(Govt). Is it that hard to get what @bradley.thm meant?
@bradley.thm and where does that money come from?
@bloodycrocodile the best scenario is that the government fork out the money for a higher paying salary AND the better living conditions
